TEXT: The applicants are NORP nationals of NORP ethnic origin . The first applicant , Mr GPE ORG , was born in DATE . The second applicant , PERSON , was born in DATE . They reside in ORG . The third applicant , Mr PERSON , was born in DATE and resides in LOC . They were represented before ORG by PERSON and PERSON B. Pleše of ORG in GPE as well as by Mr PERSON and PERSON , lawyers practising respectively in PERSON and PERSON ( GPE ) . The respondent Government were represented by PERSON , their Agent .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

In DATE , CARDINAL ORG families , including the first and the second applicant , came to work in an agricultural co - operative located in the municipality of PERSON . Shortly after their arrival , each of the families received permanent residence under NORP law in what are DATE the municipalities of ORG and PERSON .

At DATE the agricultural co - operative in PERSON ceased operations . As a result , the above GPE families lost their jobs . Since DATE at the co - operative were linked to their employment , they were compelled to leave them . DATE were subsequently destroyed .

In DATE the first and second applicant and the other GPE returned to the municipalities of GPE and ORG where they were legally registered . At various periods of time over DATE they lived in temporary housing provided by local government authorities in the district of ORG . On several occasions , hostility towards the GPE on the part of local officials or non - NORP residents forced the NORP families to flee . Thus , DATE , ORG reserved a trailer in Čabiny for the Romani families at a cost of CARDINAL NORP korunas . Although the GPE raised the money to rent the trailer , the villages of PERSON , ORG , PERSON , PERSON and PERSON did not allow them to place the trailer on their territory . After the ORG had built temporary dwellings for themselves in ORG , the dwellings were torn down by non - Romani residents . For DATE the GPE were therefore moving frequently from CARDINAL place to another , in search of a permanent and secure home .

In DATE the ORG families again established temporary dwellings on agricultural land located in the village of ORG . Local authorities , apparently responding to anti - Roma sentiment among the non - Romani majority , called a meeting on CARDINAL DATE , to deal with what they referred to as “ the problem of GPE in the district of ORG . ”

The written record indicates that the meeting took place in the premises of ORG and that it was attended by the mayors of ORG , ORG and ORG . The director of ORG of ORG and a representative of the Head of ORG were also present .

At the meeting , the director of ORG recounted the different attempts to solve the problem of the homeless GPE from the time of the destruction of their dwellings in the PERSON community in DATE . Noting the legal obligations of local authorities to address problems of shelter laid down in NORP law he observed , in particular , that there were GPE homeless in the register of ORG community and that those GPE had permanent residence in GPE , GPE and ORG .

The mayor of ORG characterised as illegal the movement of GPE to the village of ORG and warned of the “ very negative reaction of citizens in the community ” who might try to “ resolve this problem by expelling them forcibly or burning the cabins . ” The mayor also noted that there had been several conflicts between ORG citizens and the GPE . He alleged that the surface water in a nearby river basin had been polluted by the latter and asked colleagues to resolve this problem as soon as possible .

The TIME further indicate that the mayors of ORG and ORG agreed to accommodate the homeless GPE , and the director of ORG undertook to visit the mayor of PERSON to explain to him the problem discussed .
On DATE an extraordinary meeting of the municipal council of ORG adopted Resolution No . DATE . Its relevant parts provide as follows :

“ The municipality representatives unanimously agree and declare that the GPE [ concerned ] are not the native inhabitants of GPE , since they only moved to PERSON from the villages PERSON and GPE . In DATE , CARDINAL family moved into the village as the employees of the co - operative PERSON , with the assistance of the former director of the co - operative ...

In DATE ... the deputy mayor in PERSON gave the GPE permanent residence in PERSON , since PERSON was only a part of PERSON , and did not exist as a separate village . The family ’s permanent residence was registered in a house , which is occupied . [ The deputy mayor ] awarded the GPE permanent residence because DATE was DATE .
In DATE the GPE left PERSON and moved to the village PERSON to look for a job .
After the separation [ of GPE and PERSON ] in DATE , the GPE neither resided in the village nor claimed their permanent residence here . Due to this , we do not consider them to be our inhabitants .
According to the evidence from the house register , CARDINAL persons ( out of CARDINAL potentially returning to the village ) have their permanent residence in GPE : PERSON and PERSON .
Finally , the municipal council declared that , in the event the GPE forcibly settle in the village , they would be expelled beyond the district of the village with the help of all inhabitants . ”

On DATE a second meeting of the mayors was convened in ORG to address “ the problem of GPE homeless in ORG community . ” It was attended by the mayors of ORG , ORG and ORG , a representative of the mayor of GPE , the director of ORG as well as by the Head of ORG .

According to the TIME , the director of ORG recalled that both PERSON and GPE municipalities had resisted providing accommodation for the persons at issue in ORG notwithstanding that the latter were entered in their housing registers . The mayor of ORG explained that the community had no place in its property where GPE could be placed . The delegate of the mayor of PERSON reasoned that , insofar as the village of PERSON had “ inherited GPE ” from the PERSON co - operative , the problem should be solved by the co - operative . The mayor of ORG and the delegate of the mayor of ORG offered to start negotiations with the management of the co - operative . The participants agreed to meet again on DATE .

On DATE the municipal council of ORG adopted Resolution No . CARDINAL , in which it forbade NORP citizens to enter the village of Ňagov or to settle in shelters within the territory of the village . The resolution provided that its effect was of permanent duration and that the mayor was responsible for its enforcement .
On DATE the dwellings built and occupied by the first and second applicant and the other GPE in the municipality of ORG were set on fire , burned and destroyed .
The applicants submit that they have at their disposal no record indicating that the prosecution authorities have taken necessary measures with a view to investigating the offence .

The Government maintain that the cabins had been built unlawfully and that the incident was not examined by the police as the persons concerned did not file a complaint . They further refer to statements by local inhabitants according to which the GPE involved had carried away all their clothes and valuable property before the cabins burned down . The inhabitants expressed the view that the GPE had probably set their cabins on fire deliberately with a view to forcing the public authorities to resolve their housing problem .

In an interview published in the daily PERSON on DATE the director of ORG of ORG expressed the view that the citizens of ORG had been able to solve the situation with violence which was not acceptable . He further explained that the ORG administration had no possibility of ordering the mayors to abide by the law .

On DATE a third meeting was convened in ORG . The TIME state that the above resolution of the Ňagov municipality was contrary to the relevant law because GPE homeless had permanent residence in that village . TIME continued that “ considering that the present illegal dwelling in the ORG community was terminated by the community , the GPE homeless were recommended to address themselves to municipal offices in the communities where they have permanent residence ” .

In DATE , ORG of the Good Roma Fairy Kesay Foundation in GPE , GPE , ( “ ORG ” ) , where the third applicant was employed as a researcher , sent a letter to ORG in GPE requesting an investigation into the legality of the above resolutions of the GPE and ORG municipalities . The letter asserted that the resolutions were acts of public discrimination against GPE , and that they violated the rights to freedom of movement and residence and to protection against discrimination .
On DATE ORG informed ORG that the investigation had been assigned to ORG in GPE .

In a letter dated DATE ORG provided ORG with the names of CARDINAL persons from Ňagov , including the first applicant , and CARDINAL persons from GPE , including the second applicant , and explained that they considered that their fundamental human rights had been violated by the above municipal resolutions .

On DATE ORG submitted a petition to ORG ( Ústavný súd ) pursuant to LAW . It claimed that the above ORG and GPE municipal resolutions be quashed as they violated Articles CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) , CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the LAW .
On DATE ORG dismissed the petition . The decision stated that , in view of its contents , ORG had entertained it as a constitutional complaint under LAW .

ORG noted that the rights invoked by the petitioner were designed to protect only natural persons . Since ORG was a legal person , it could not have suffered an infringement of those rights . The decision stated that individuals affected by the decisions in question were free to file a constitutional complaint alleging a violation of their fundamental rights or freedoms .
On DATE ORG notified ORG that , in view of ORG ruling , it had suspended the investigation concerning the challenged resolutions .

On DATE the first and the third applicant filed , together with another person , a petition with the Constitutional Court pursuant to LAW . They claimed that ORG should find a violation of their rights under LAW , DATE ( CARDINAL ) and CARDINAL of the LAW in that ORG . CARDINAL of the NORP municipal council unlawfully restricted the freedom of movement and residence of a group of people solely because they were GPE . They argued that all GPE in GPE suffered infringements in this respect .

On DATE , the second applicant filed a separate petition to ORG with reference to the NORP municipal council ’s ORG . CARDINAL of DATE . She argued that the resolution violated her rights to freedom of movement and residence , freedom from racial and ethnic discrimination and freedom in the choice of nationality .

By CARDINAL decisions delivered on DATE a different chamber of ORG dismissed both petitions . As to the first and second applicant , ORG held that they had not shown that the respective municipal authorities had applied the resolutions in question in a manner which would infringe the rights invoked by them . As regards the third applicant , ORG noted that he had permanent residence outside the ORG district and found no evidence that he had tried to enter or move into the community of ORG , or that the community had tried to stop him from doing so . It concluded that the third applicant could not claim to be a victim of a violation of his constitutional rights .

After the adoption of the resolutions in question the first and the second applicant , as well as their families , wanted to return respectively to ORG and PERSON . However , they did not return because they feared that the resolutions would be enforced , possibly by violence .

On DATE the NORP municipal council amended its above ORG . CARDINAL of DATE by declaring that it could not agree with the accommodation of NORP citizens within the village as the latter had no work and possessed neither property nor housing facilities in GPE , and did not come from there .
On DATE the ORG for human rights of ORG requested ORG to review the lawfulness of the municipal resolutions in question and to take action which might be necessary .

On DATE ORG participated at the respective meetings of the municipal councils in GPE and PERSON at which the contested resolutions were quashed by unanimous vote . In particular , the resolution of DATE adopted by the municipal council of ORG expressly stated that the resolution No . CARDINAL of DATE had not respected human rights and freedoms .

On DATE the Government passed a resolution by which it made available CARDINAL NORP korunas with a view to resolving the housing problem of the NORP families from the area of GPE and PERSON . A housing facility in ORG was purchased and rebuilt for this purpose . As from DATE it has been put at the disposal of the NORP families who had previously lived in wooden cabins situated in the area in question , including the families of the first and second applicant .
Constitutional provisions
The following relevant provisions of the LAW were in force at the period under consideration .
LAW ) prohibits discrimination in the enjoyment of fundamental rights and freedoms .
LAW ) prohibits torture , inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment .
Under LAW ) , every person has the right to protection against unjustified interference with his or her private and family life .
LAW ) guarantees the right to respect for one ’s home .
DATE ) guarantees the freedom of movement and residence .
Article CARDINAL provides that no one may suffer harm on the ground that he or she belongs to a national or ethnic minority .

Pursuant to LAW , the ORG shall review the challenges to final decisions made by central governmental authorities , local governmental authorities and local self - governmental bodies in cases concerning violations of fundamental rights and freedoms of citizens , unless the protection of such rights falls under the jurisdiction of another court .
LAW ) provides that ORG may commence proceedings upon a petition ( “ podnet ” ) submitted by legal entities or individuals claiming a violation of their rights .
LAW of DATE , as in force at the relevant time

Pursuant to LAW , a constitutional complaint could be filed by individuals or legal persons alleging a violation of their fundamental rights or freedoms , by a decision of CARDINAL of the authorities set out in LAW , unless the protection of such rights or freedoms fell under the jurisdiction of another court .

Under LAW ( CARDINAL ) , a constitutional complaint was to be lodged within DATE from DATE when the decision in question became final or , as the case might be , from the moment when a person ’s fundamental rights or freedoms were violated as a result of such a decision .

Section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) entitled ORG to quash the challenged decision when it found , in proceedings brought upon a constitutional complaint , that a person ’s fundamental rights or freedoms had been violated .
Practice of ORG

In its finding no . I. ÚS/CARDINAL of DATE the ORG found , upon a constitutional complaint lodged pursuant to LAW , that a municipal council ’s decision concerning a local vote had violated the ORG constitutional right to participate in the administration of public matters . In the same finding ORG quashed the relevant municipal decision pursuant to LAW of LAW of DATE . A similar ORG finding was delivered , in respect of a decision of a different municipality , on DATE ( no . I. ÚS CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) .

ORG consistently held that , in the context of proceedings under LAW ) of the LAW , it lacked jurisdiction to draw legal consequences from its finding of a violation of a petitioner ’s constitutional right . It could neither grant damages to the person concerned nor impose a sanction on the public authority liable for the violation found . ORG considered that it was therefore for the authority concerned to provide redress to the person whose constitutional rights were violated .
Practice of ORG

In its opinion adopted on DATE ORG found , upon a communication concerning the same facts as the present case but submitted by a different person , that the municipal resolutions in question , while in force , had violated LAW ) ( i ) of LAW on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination which reads as follows :

“ In compliance with the fundamental obligations laid down in LAW undertake to prohibit and to eliminate racial discrimination in all its forms and to guarantee the right of everyone , without distinction as to race , colour , or national or ethnic origin , to equality before the law , notably in the enjoyment of the following rights : ...
( d ) Other civil rights , in particular :
( i ) The right to freedom of movement and residence within the border of the ORG ; ”

The ORG further noted that the resolutions had been rescinded in DATE and invited the NORP authorities to take necessary measures to ensure that practices restricting the freedom of movement and residence of GPE under their jurisdiction be fully and promptly eliminated .
